title: 110_hr1679
content: The Act may be cited as the "Caribbean Coral Reef Protection Act" and includes a statement of policy. The "Caribbean Coral Reef Protection Act" aims to deny Cuba resources that threaten US national security, Florida's marine environment, and the environment off Cuba's coast to prevent prolonging the dictatorship. The "Caribbean Coral Reef Protection Act" targets Cuba's natural resources and aims to prevent the prolonging of the dictatorship by deterring foreign investments in developing petroleum resources. The Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 is amended to exclude aliens who contribute to Cuba's development of petroleum resources off its coast. The Secretary of State will deny visas and exclude aliens from the US who invest over $1,000,000 in Cuba to enhance its government's capabilities. The Secretary of State may deny visas and exclude individuals from the US who invest over $1,000,000 in Cuba to enhance its government's ability to develop petroleum resources off Cuba's coast. The Secretary of State can waive visa restrictions for individuals for critical medical reasons or litigation purposes. The Act defines terms like 'agent' and 'instrumentality' to include the Cuban Communist Party. It also defines 'develop' in relation to petroleum resources and 'investment' as specific activities undertaken. The Act defines 'investment' as activities related to petroleum resources undertaken with the Cuban government or entities in Cuba after January 10, 2005. Investment activities in Cuba after January 10, 2005 include contracts for petroleum development, purchasing ownership shares, and participating in royalties or profits. Investment activities in Cuba after January 10, 2005 include purchasing ownership shares, participating in royalties or profits, and selling goods, services, or technology related to petroleum development. The amendment applies to aliens seeking admission to the United States on or after the enactment date of the Act, regarding the sale or purchase of goods, services, or technology related to petroleum resources. SEC. 4 imposes sanctions and prohibits the facilitation of Cuba's petroleum resources development. If the President determines that a person has made an investment of $1,000,000 or more contributing to Cuba's petroleum development or trafficked in confiscated US property after January 10, 2005, sanctions will be imposed. If a person invests in Cuba's petroleum development or traffics in confiscated US property, the President will impose sanctions such as prohibiting loans and guarantees and export sanctions. The President will impose sanctions on any person investing in Cuba's petroleum development or trafficking in confiscated US property, including prohibiting loans, guarantees, and export of goods or technology to sanctioned persons under various acts. Sanctions may be imposed on a sanctioned person who is a financial institution, including a prohibition on designation as a primary dealer. Prohibitions on financial institutions may include a ban on being designated as a primary dealer in US Government debt instruments. Financial institutions may be prohibited from being designated as primary dealers in US Government debt instruments and from serving as agents or repositories for US Government funds. Sanctions imposed under these prohibitions are considered as one sanction for the purposes of this section. Sanctions may include prohibiting financial institutions from being primary dealers in US Government debt and serving as repositories for US Government funds. Sanctions imposed are considered as one sanction for this section. The government is prohibited from procuring goods or services from sanctioned individuals. Sanctions will end if the President certifies that certain requirements have been met. Additionally, US persons are forbidden from assisting Cuba in developing petroleum resources. The US government is prohibited from procuring goods or services from sanctioned individuals. Sanctions will end if specific requirements are met. US persons are also forbidden from assisting Cuba in developing petroleum resources, specifically in the submerged lands off Cuba's coast. The Secretary of State must submit reports every 180 days to relevant committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. The Secretary of State must report every 180 days to relevant committees on investments over $1,000,000 that enhance Cuba's ability to develop petroleum resources in submerged lands off its coast. The Secretary of State must report every 180 days on investments exceeding $1,000,000 that enhance Cuba's ability to develop petroleum resources in submerged lands off its coast, including details on the investments and any sanctions imposed as a result. The report must include details on investments exceeding $1,000,000 that enhance Cuba's ability to develop petroleum resources in submerged lands, along with information on any sanctions imposed as a result. Additionally, investments in trafficking confiscated US property that contribute to this enhancement must be reported, including the values of the investments, identities of the investors, and the confiscated property involved. The Secretary of State, in consultation with other agencies, must provide annual reports to specific committees on investments in Cuba's petroleum resources and any sanctions imposed as a result. The Secretary of State, along with other agencies, must submit an annual report to congressional committees on the impact of Cuba's petroleum development on the environment and natural resources of submerged lands off Cuba's coast and Florida's marine environment. The Secretary of State must assess the impact of Cuba's petroleum development on the environment and natural resources of submerged lands off Cuba's coast and Florida's marine environment, using environmental impact statements as a model. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, terms like "appropriate congressional committees", "confiscated", "person", "property", and "traffics" are defined as per the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity (LIBERTAD) Act of 1996. Additionally, terms like "develop", "investment", and "petroleum resources" are defined in section 402(c) of the Act. The terms "agent" and "instrumentality" are also clarified. In this Act, the terms "agent" and "instrumentality" shall include the Cuban Communist Party.
